text: The Death and Descendants of Abraham
Now Abraham again took a wife, and her name \add was\add* Keturah.
And she bore to him Zimran, Jokshan, Medan, Midian, Ishbak, and Shuah.
And Jokshan fathered Sheba and Dedan. And the sons of Dedan were Asshurim and Letushim and Leummim.
And the sons of Midian \add were\add* Ephah, Epher, Hanoch, Abidah, and Eldaah. All of these \add were\add* the children of Keturah.
And Abraham gave all he had to Isaac.
But to the sons of Abraham’s concubines Abraham gave gifts. And while he \add was\add* still living he sent them away eastward, \add away\add* from his son Isaac, to the land of the east.
Now these \add are\add* the days of the years of ⸤the life of Abraham⸥:\f + \fr 25:7 \ft Literally “the years of the life of Abraham which he lived” \f* one hundred and seventy-five years.
And Abraham passed away and died in a good old age, old and full of years. And he was gathered to his people.
And Isaac and Ishmael his sons buried him in the cave of Machpelah, in the field of Ephron, son of Zohar the Hittite, that \add was\add* east of Mamre,
the field that Abraham had bought from the Hittites.\f + \fr 25:10 \ft Or “sons of Heth” \f* There Abraham was buried and Sarah his wife.
And it happened \add that\add* after the death of Abraham God blessed Isaac his son, and Isaac settled at Beer-Lahai-Roi.
Now these \add are\add* the generations\f + \fr 25:12 \ft Or “family records” \f* of Ishmael, the son of Abraham, that Hagar the Egyptian, the maidservant of Sarah, bore to Abraham.
And these are the names of the sons of Ishmael, by their names according to their family records. The firstborn of Ishmael \add was\add* Nebaioth, then Kedar, Adbeel, Mibsam,
Mishma, Dumah, Massa,
Hadad, Tema, Jetur, Naphish, and Kedemah.
These \add are\add* the sons of Ishmael, and these \add are\add* their names by their villages and by their encampments—12 leaders according to their tribes.
Now these \add are\add* the years of the life of Ishmael: 137 years. And he passed away and died, and was gathered to his people.

They settled from Havilah to Shur, which \add was\add* opposite\f + \fr 25:18 \ft Or “upon the face of” \f* Egypt, going toward Asshur, opposite;\f + \fr 25:18 \ft Or “upon the face of” \f* he ⸤settled⸥\f + \fr 25:18 \ft Literally “fell” \f* opposite\f + \fr 25:18 \ft Or “upon the face of” \f* all his brothers.
Jacob and Esau
Now these \add are\add* the generations\f + \fr 25:19 \ft Or “family records” \f* of Isaac, the son of Abraham. Abraham fathered Isaac,

And Isaac was ⸤forty years old⸥\f + \fr 25:20 \ft Literally “a son of forty years” \f* when he took Rebekah, the daughter of Bethuel the Aramean of Paddan-Aram, the sister of Laban the Aramean, as his wife.
And Isaac prayed to Yahweh on behalf of his wife, for she \add was\add* barren. And Yahweh responded to his prayer, and Rebekah his wife conceived.

And the children in her womb jostled each other, and she said, “⸤If it is going to be like this, why be pregnant⸥?”\f + \fr 25:22 \ft Literally “if so, why this I?” \f* And she went to inquire of Yahweh.

And Yahweh said to her, “Two nations \add are\add* in your womb, and two peoples ⸤from birth⸥\f + \fr 25:23 \ft Literally “from your bowels” \f* shall be divided. And ⸤one people shall be stronger than the other⸥.\f + \fr 25:23 \ft Literally “people than people shall be stronger” \f* And \add the\add* elder shall serve \add the\add* younger.”
And when her days to give birth were completed,\f + \fr 25:24 \ft Or “full” \f* then—behold—twins \add were\add* in her womb.
And the first came out red, all ⸤his body⸥\f + \fr 25:25 \ft Literally “of him” \f* \add was\add* like a hairy coat, so they called his name Esau.

And afterward his brother came out, and his hand grasped the heel of Esau, so his name was called Jacob. And Isaac ⸤was sixty years old⸥\f + \fr 25:26 \ft Literally “a son of sixty years” \f* at their birth.

And the boys grew up. And Esau \add was\add* a skilled\f + \fr 25:27 \ft Or “knowing” (knowledgeable) \f* hunter, a man of the field, but Jacob \add was\add* a peaceful man, living \add in\add* tents.
And Isaac loved Esau because ⸤he could eat of his game⸥,\f + \fr 25:28 \ft Literally “game in his mouth” \f* but Rebekah loved Jacob.
Once\f + \fr 25:29 \ft Or “and” \f* Jacob cooked a thick stew, and Esau came in from the field, and he was exhausted.
And Esau said to Jacob, “Give me ⸤some of that red stuff⸥\f + \fr 25:30 \ft Literally “some of the red, this red” \f* to gulp down, for I am exhausted!” (Therefore his name was called Edom).
Then Jacob said, “Sell me your birthright ⸤first⸥.”\f + \fr 25:31 \ft Literally “as the day” \f*
And Esau said, “Look, I am going to die; now what \add is\add* this birthright to me?”
Then Jacob said, “Swear to me ⸤first⸥.”\f + \fr 25:33 \ft Literally “as the day” \f* And he swore to him, and sold his birthright to Jacob.
Then Jacob gave Esau bread, and thick lentil stew, and he ate and drank. Then he got up and went away. So Esau despised his birthright.
